comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Rear Admiral Aaron Ward: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Ward_%28sailor%29 His obituary mentions his wife and two daughters surviving him: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00716F93C5A11738... www.history.navy.mil/danfs/a1/aaron_ward-i.htm One of his two surviving daughters was artist Hlida Ward (d. 1950); as her sister Edna was married (Mrs. Washington Lee Capps), I'm thinking Hilda's the Miss Ward here: books.google.com/books?id=XKSk1TO99KUC&lpg=PA100&... Mrs. Ward was Annie Cairns Willis Ward: stuffnobodycaresabout.com/2012/03/13/a-photographic-trip-... www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pv&GRid=41740866 Annie Cairns Willis Ward was the daughter of composer Richard Storrs Willis, and niece of author Fanny Fern (aka Sara Willis): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Storrs_Willis en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fanny_Fern

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The New York sun., March 26, 1913, Page 14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1913-03-26/ed-... mentions an assemblyman Thomas B. Maloney of Nassau, a member of the New York Consolidated Exchange. A brief bio is in the New York Red Book published in 1913. books.google.com/books?id=kHBIAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA161&l... Maloney represented Nassau County, which includes Great Neck (where Ward was speaking at the Labor Day celebrations in a neighboring picture). So this is probably also on Labor Day, 1915.

comment._content: Thanks for the info!  We'll update record.
